list_definition.definition: (sometimes with intoor from) to place, take, keep or force apart

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He separated the money into two piles
A policeman tried to separate the men who were fighting.
We all walked along together and separated at the crossroads.

list_definition.definition: (of a husband and wife) to start living apart from each other by choice

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He sawed the wood into four separate pieces
The garage is separate from the house.
This happened on two separate occasions
I like to keep my job and my home life separate.

list_ex_of_english: The digested samples were electrophoretically separated on 8% polyacrylamide gels.
Genes abut one another or are separated by short intergenic sequences.
They further argue that there is "no time and no task" in which reasoning can be separated from perceiving, acting, and remembering.
She just yelled through the open door that separated the reception area from his office.
We say that this approach is effector-based because it makes effector knowledge explicit, and separates it from the rest of the planning knowledge.
Each time the roller passed over the flax stem some of the shive separated from the fibre.
In physical health problems there may be a desire to identify a disease entity that can be diagnosed and separated from the sense of self.
How well separated could we expect the factors in a factorization to be?
